name: Doro Wot
recipe: Cook onions with oil and berbere until soft, add chicken and simmer. Serve with boiled eggs.
tip: High in protein — good for muscle building.
culture: Doro Wot is a holiday and wedding dish across Ethiopia.

name: Shiro Wot
recipe: Cook onion, garlic, and berbere in oil. Add water and shiro flour until thickened.
tip: Perfect for vegans and high in fiber.
culture: A daily staple in many Ethiopian homes, especially during fasting.

name: Genfo
recipe: Cook barley flour in boiling water until thick. Serve with niter kibbeh and berbere center.
tip: Traditional breakfast that gives long-lasting energy.
culture: Popular during cold mornings in highland Ethiopia.

name: Firfir
recipe: Tear injera into small pieces and mix with spiced oil and onion.
tip: A good leftover breakfast full of fiber.
culture: Often made with leftover injera; served for breakfast.

name: Atmit
recipe: Cook oats and barley in milk or water. Sweeten with sugar.
tip: Great for recovery and nursing mothers.
culture: Used to nourish new mothers and sick people.

name: Chechebsa
recipe: Cut flatbread into pieces, fry in butter, mix with berbere.
tip: Popular among students for quick energy.

name: Kik Alicha
recipe: Boil peas until soft, sauté onion with turmeric, mix together.
tip: Easy on the stomach — good for light meals.

name: Misir Wot
recipe: Cook lentils until soft. Fry onion and berbere, mix with lentils.
culture: Often eaten with injera, especially on fasting days.

name: Ayib
recipe: Boil milk and add lemon juice to separate curds. Strain to make cheese.
tip: Low in fat — balances spicy food.
culture: Often served with spicy wot to reduce heat.

name: Gomen
recipe: Cook chopped greens with garlic, onion, and oil.
culture: A healthy green side dish eaten with many meals.

name: Kinch
recipe: Boil bulgur, mix with melted niter kibbeh and salt.
tip: A simple and filling breakfast or side dish.
culture: Minimalist food for both poor and wealthy homes.

name: Beyaynetu
recipe: Serve small portions of various vegan wots over injera.
culture: Typical fasting meal on Wednesdays and Fridays.

name: Tibs
recipe: Fry beef with onions and spices. Serve hot.
tip: Great for athletes and high-protein diets.
culture: Often eaten during holidays and special occasions.
